thread.title: Delta Air Lines to allow passengers to upgrade their flight to private jet
thread.title_full: Delta Air Lines to allow passengers to upgrade their flight to private jet | Daily Mail Online

author: Becky Pemberton For Mailonline
title: Delta Air Lines to allow passengers to upgrade their flight to private jet
text:
26 shares 4
View
comments
Being moved to a first class seat on a flight is regarded as the ultimate upgrade - but Delta Air Lines have thrown the rule book away.
The carrier, from as soon as this week, will be offering 'high value customers' the chance to be upgraded to one of its private jets.
The majority of the upgrades, however, will be offered just a day or two before departure, and only to those who have achieved elite or 'medallion' status in Delta's SkyMiles frequent-flyer program.
Scroll down for video
From as soon as this week Delta Air Lines will be offering the once-in-a-lifetime opportunity for 'high value customers' to board one of its private jets (pictured) as part of a new upgrade package
New Victor app lets you charter private jets using mobile phone The upgrades will run from $300 (£192) to $800 (£512) per trip with plans to focus the scheme on travellers flying on the East Coast, according to Bloomberg .
And the lucky few will be given the chance to board one of the company's 66-plane Delta Private Jets fleet.
The option was initially going to be restricted to those who have obtained the 'diamond medallion' level which includes travelling at least 125,000 miles or 140 flight segments per year, spending at least $15,000 (£9,612) annually.
However, the luxury treatment will actually be opened up to include those in the lower elite tier who rack up 25,000 miles or 30 segments annually, spending $3,000 (£1,921) a year.
 Era of fumbling for your boarding pass could be over: Alaska... British family's four star 'holiday from hell': Tourists are... Mixing business with pleasure: Infographic reveals 27% binge... 'End of an era' as Madrid's oldest cafe shuts its doors... 26 shares Not only providing the chance to reward its most dedicated fliers, the airline hopes the offer will prove a solution to the costly problem of empty leg flights on its expensive jets.
These are caused when private jets are forced to travel to another airport with empty seats.
Ultimately Delta Air Lines hopes the taste of the finer things in life will tempt the upgraded clientèle, who would not normally have considered travelling by private jet, to opt for the high life again in the future.
The upgrades will run from $300 (£192) to $800 (£512) per trip with plans to focus the scheme on travellers flying on the East Coast
Read more: Delta Is About to Allow Some Commercial Passengers to Upgrade to a Private Jet - Bloomberg Business Bloomberg
